titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the H.M. Tomlinson Collection
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 04:14

did.unittitle: H. M. Tomlinson collection

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Correspondence and writings by and about H. M. Tomlinson. Tomlinson's correspondents include William McFee, James T. Babb, and Eugene Saxon. There is office correspondence and memos from Harper & Brothers' office files relating to Tomlinson, and letters to James T. Babb and John Archer Gee about Tomlinson. Writings include typescript drafts, with corrections, of All Our Yesterdays, Gallion's Reach, as well as autograph manuscripts and typescripts of various essays.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Ongoing collection of documents acquired by gift and purchase from various sources. Type of accession (gift or purchase) and date of acquisition is noted in the box-and-folder list. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Henry Major Tomlinson Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Henry Major Tomlinson Collection. General Collection. Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Restricted Fragile Papers , in box 6 and cold storage, may only be consulted with permission of the appropriate curator. Preservation photocopies and copy prints for reference use have been substituted in the main files.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced from previously existing cards in the Manuscripts Catalog, or from another inventory. All pertinent bibliographical information has been retained. If the collection also contains unlisted or unsorted material, it has been noted in the box-and-folder list. This finding aid will be updated periodically to account for new materials that may be added to the collection. The date of the most recent update is noted on the title page. For information on material that may have been added since the last update, please consult the Public Service Desk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This finding aid encompasses accessions of single manuscripts and small groups of manuscripts and other papers, by or pertaining to H. M. Tomlinson, which the library has chosen to group and list as an artificial collection. Materials incorporated into the collection prior to July 1997 have been organized into three series. Series I consists of materials that were gifts of James T. Babb, 1942-1968. Series II consists of materials that were a gift of Harper & Brothers. Series III consists of additional materials acquired by gift and purchase from various sources.

CORRESPONDENCE
Letters from H. M. Tomlinson
ALS to Mr. Austin, South Croydon

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Advising him to "cash in" on his travel experiences

did.unittitle: 4 ALS to James T. Babb

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Chiefly concerning a Tomlinson bibliography, and the disposition of various manuscripts. Mention is made of Joseph Conrad and Thomas Hardy. In the letter of 1953 Jul 16, Tomlinson comments on changing literary standards and expresses surprise at William McFee's literary difficulties in America

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Reference surrogates have been substituted in the main files. For further information consult the appropriate curator.
